newsitem.title: USA: U.S. cities boost role in global economy - survey.
newsitem.headline: U.S. cities boost role in global economy - survey.

text.p: U.S. cities have become aggressive players in the global marketplace, hoping to bolster their economies with foreign investment and tourism, according to a report released Wednesday.

Nearly half of the cities surveyed said they were working to promote exports of local products and more than one-third said they were actively trying to attract foreign investment, the survey, conducted by the National League of Cities, said.
"Our own cities aren't just waiting for something to happen," said Donald Borut, the league's executive director. "There is an enormous amount of global activity."

The league said 48 percent of U.S. municipalities have active sister-city relations with cities in other countries, 34 percent are involved in cultural exchanges and 24 percent are promoting their city to foreign tourists.
Thirty-five percent said they work actively with state officials, and 20 percent with federal agencies to develop partnerships focusing on international opportunities.
Fifty-nine percent of respondents said the increase of global economic competition has been positive or very positive for their communities, according to the survey.
Nearly two out of three local leaders said globalization was improving the well-being of all city residents, with high-income and highly-skilled workers gaining the most.
The survey was based on a random sample of mayors and other officials across the United States. A total of 476 usable responses were received, the league said.
